senses.de: Having the right to do or get something
senses.ex: She is eligible to run for election.

Tips.title: Eligibility Criteria
Tips.description: Understand the specific criteria making someone eligible for a right, benefit, or position.
Tips.example: You must be over 18 to be eligible to vote.

Tips.title: Conditional Right
Tips.description: 'Eligible' often means having a conditional right that depends on meeting certain requirements.
Tips.example: Only eligible members can access the club lounge.

Tips.title: Opportunity Access
Tips.description: 'Eligible' can imply the opportunity to access something exclusive or beneficial.
Tips.example: As a student, you are eligible for discounted fares.

senses.de: Desirable or suitable, especially for marriage
senses.ex: He is one of the most eligible bachelors in town.

Tips.title: Social Suitability
Tips.description: Reflects societal standards of what is considered desirable or suitable, often regarding marriage.
Tips.example: In social circles, she's considered an eligible match.

Tips.title: Cultural Preference
Tips.description: Understand that 'eligible bachelor/spinster' can carry traditional cultural preferences regarding partners.
Tips.example: He's seen as an eligible bachelor because of his career and charm.

senses.ex: Due to his good behavior, he is eligible for parole.

Tips.title: Merit-Based Eligibility
Tips.description: 'Eligible' can refer to being considered worthy due to merit, such as good behavior or performance.
Tips.example: She's eligible for the 'Employee of the Month' award.

Tips.title: Recognition Eligibility
Tips.description: Can mean being worthy of recognition or a special opportunity because of one's efforts or achievements.
Tips.example: After years of hard work, he is now eligible for tenure.

Able.wordDefinition:
Able means having the capability or power to do something. It implies that a person has the necessary skills and resources to accomplish a task or goal.

Able means having the ability to do something, while eligible means meeting the qualifications or requirements to do something.

Accept.wordDefinition:
Accept means to take or receive something that is offered or given. It is applicable when someone is given something that they are willing to take.

For example, if someone is offered a scholarship, they can choose to accept it or not.

Admissible.wordDefinition:
Both admissible and eligible refer to something or someone meeting certain requirements or criteria, but they are used in different contexts.

Admissible generally refers to evidence or information that can be used in a legal case. It means that the evidence or information is valid, relevant, and meets a certain standard (such as being obtained legally).

For example, a confession may be deemed admissible in court if it was obtained voluntarily and without coercion.

Admissible is used in a legal sense, while eligible is used more broadly to refer to qualifications or entitlements.

Entitle.wordDefinition:
Entitle means having a right to something, especially as a result of meeting certain conditions. For example, if you buy a ticket to a concert, you are entitled to attend the concert because you have met the condition of purchasing the ticket.

In short, eligibility means being qualified, while entitlement means having a right to something. Eligibility applies to opportunities or benefits, while entitlement refers to rights.

Fit.wordDefinition:
Fit means suitable or appropriate for a particular situation or purpose. For example, if you are fit to play a sport, it means you have the necessary physical abilities and skills to do so.

So, eligibility is about meeting requirements while fitness is about being suitable for a specific task. Eligibility is used when there are rules or standards to be met, while fitness is used when there is a specific task or goal in mind.

Meet.wordDefinition:
Eligible refers to meeting the criteria or requirements to qualify for something, such as receiving a scholarship or being allowed to vote.

It means that you are qualified or allowed to do something.

Meet means to fulfill or satisfy a requirement or expectation.

It is used when there is a certain standard or criteria that needs to be met. For example, if you have to get a certain grade to pass a class, you need to meet that grade to pass.

Eligible means you qualify for something based on predetermined criteria, while meet means that you have satisfied the criteria or requirements for something.

Qualified.wordDefinition:
Qualified means that someone has the necessary skills, knowledge or expertise to successfully perform a particular role or task.

For example, if you have the required education, training and experience, you are qualified to work in a certain profession.

Eligible refers to meeting the criteria to apply for something, while qualified refers to having the necessary skills, training or experience to do something well.

Suitable.wordDefinition: Suitable means something is appropriate or fitting for a particular purpose or situation. For example, if you are looking for a new job, you might say a certain position is suitable for you if it matches your skills and interests.

quotes.Text: I marketed pens - on the phone. But the beauty of the gig was that you had to call these strangers and say, 'Hi, how ya doing?' You made up a name, like, 'Hey, it's Edward Quartermaine from California. You're eligible to receive this grandfather clock or a trip to Tahiti.' You promise them all these things if they buy a gross of pens.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Johnny Depp

quotes.Text: There is one thing in this good old world that is positively sure - happiness is for all who strive to be happy - and those who laugh are happy. Everybody is eligible - you - me - the other fellow. Happiness is fundamentally a state of mind - not a state of body.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Douglas Fairbanks

quotes.Text: We must reject the cynicism that says allowing every eligible vote to be cast and counted is a 'power grab.' Americans understand that these are the values our brave men and women in uniform and our veterans risk their lives to defend.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Stacey Abrams

quotes.Text: It's so deeply disturbing to me that half of the eligible voters don't vote in this country. We talk about how divided the country is. The truth is, we don't even know. We just know what the half that voted thought.
quotes.Title: American Businesswoman
quotes.Name: Christie Hefner

quotes.Text: A society that thinks the choice between ways of living is just a choice between equally eligible 'lifestyles' turns universities into academic cafeterias offering junk food for the mind.
quotes.Title: Journalist
quotes.Name: George Will

quotes.Text: If you're an adult, if you are eligible to be drafted and vote, then there's a certain amount of decision-making power, and I think we have to be respectful of that.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Mac Thornberry

quotes.Text: It's not that some players shouldn't be in school; it's just that universities should help them more - instead of just finding ways to keep them eligible.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Josh Rosen

quotes.Text: The life of an actor is very hard irrespective of the continent you are in. It is doubly hard when you are only eligible for minority roles.
quotes.Title: Indian Actor
quotes.Name: Kabir Bedi

quotes.Text: In our country, you need to be married to be eligible for many things, and to have a right on your partner's life.
quotes.Title: Indian Actress
quotes.Name: Suhasini Mulay

quotes.Text: You can wipe out your opponents. But if you do it unjustly you become eligible for being wiped out yourself.
quotes.Title: American Novelist
quotes.Name: Ernest Hemingway
